sn12.22:1.2: “Mendicants, a Realized One has ten powers and four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
sn12.22:1.3: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
sn12.22:1.4: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.
sn12.22:1.5: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
sn12.22:1.6: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
sn12.22:1.7: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.
sn12.22:1.8: When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.
sn12.22:1.9: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases. That is:
sn12.22:1.10: Ignorance is a condition for choices.
sn12.22:1.11: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn12.22:1.12: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn12.22:1.13: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
sn12.22:1.15: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
sn12.22:2.1: So the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
sn12.22:2.2: Just this much is quite enough for a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith to rouse up his energy.
sn12.22:2.3: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and tendons remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’
sn12.22:3.1: A lazy person lives in suffering, mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities, and ruins a great deal of their own good.
sn12.22:3.2: An energetic person lives happily, secluded from bad, unskillful qualities, and fulfills a great deal of their own good.
sn12.22:3.3: The best isn’t reached by the worst.
sn12.22:3.4: The best is reached by the best.
sn12.22:3.5: This spiritual life is the cream, mendicants, and the Teacher is before you.
sn12.22:3.6: So you should rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized, thinking:
sn12.22:3.7: ‘In this way our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.
sn12.22:3.8: And our use of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick shall be of great fruit and benefit for those who offered them.’
sn12.22:3.10: Considering your own good, mendicants, is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.
sn12.22:3.11: Considering the good of others is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.
sn12.22:3.12: Considering the good of both is quite enough for you to persist with diligence.”
